traditions.title: Ancestral Traditions

about.title: Our Mission
about.description: To promote and preserve the cultural richness of rural communities, sharing our history, traditions and way of life with the world. We believe in the importance of keeping our roots alive while embracing the future.

clothing.title: Traditional Clothing
clothing.description: Each garment tells a story. Our textiles are hand-woven using ancestral techniques, with natural colors representing elements of nature: the green of the mountains, the blue of the sky, the red of the fertile earth.

language.title: Mother Tongue
language.description: Kichwa is more than a language, it is the voice of our ancestors. Through it we transmit knowledge, stories and the Andean worldview that connects us with Pachamama.

values.title: Community Values
values.description: We live by principles of reciprocity (ayni), mutual respect and harmony with nature. The community is our extended family, where we all support each other.

crafts.title: Handicrafts
crafts.description: Our hands create functional art: ceramics, textiles, basketry. Each piece carries the soul of the artisan and the wisdom of generations.

daily.title: Daily Life
daily.description: Our days begin with the rooster's crow and the aroma of toasted corn. We work the land, care for animals and share moments with family. Life flows to the rhythm of the seasons and cycles of nature.

agriculture.title: Ancestral Agriculture
agriculture.description: We cultivate the land as our grandparents did, respecting lunar cycles and nature's signs. Corn, potato, quinoa and beans are our sacred foods.

organization.title: Social Organization
organization.description: Our community is organized democratically. Important decisions are made in assemblies where every voice counts. Leaders are chosen for their wisdom and commitment to the common good.

events.title: Community Events
events.description: We gather to celebrate harvests, weddings, baptisms and festivities. Each event strengthens the bonds that unite us as a people.

inti.name: Inti Raymi
inti.description: The festival of the Sun, celebration of the winter solstice where we thank Taita Inti for the harvests and renew our connection with the cosmos.

pawkar.name: Pawkar Raymi
pawkar.description: Celebration of blooming, where we welcome spring with dances, music and fertility rituals.

kulla.name: Kulla Raymi
kulla.description: Festival of femininity and the moon, honoring women and the feminine energy of Pachamama.

music.title: Music and Dance
music.description: Our traditional instruments - the rondador, quena, bombo - create melodies that tell stories of love, work and celebration. Each dance has a deep meaning.

rituals.title: Sacred Rituals
rituals.description: We maintain ancestral ceremonies to thank Pachamama, ask for good harvests and maintain balance between the material and spiritual worlds.

stories.title: Oral Tradition
stories.description: Elders are our living libraries. Through tales and legends they transmit teachings about respect, courage and wisdom.

q1.question: Can I visit the community?
q1.answer: Yes! We welcome respectful visitors who wish to learn about our culture. Contact us to coordinate your visit.

q2.question: How can I support the community?
q2.answer: You can support us by buying our handicrafts, participating in community tourism programs or collaborating with educational projects.

q3.question: Do you offer cultural workshops?
q3.answer: Yes, we organize workshops on weaving, ceramics, traditional cooking and Kichwa language. Check availability.
